content: How can I help you today?

I'm not sure where to start, but my wife thought seeing someone might help. Things have been really hard at home with my son acting out, and it's affecting everything—me, my marriage, even my focus at work. I just feel like I'm stuck and don’t know what to do.

It sounds like things have been really overwhelming for you lately, with challenges at home spilling over into other areas of your life. It must be tough to feel stuck and unsure of what steps to take next. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been going on and how it’s been affecting you?

Yeah, I mean, my son has been acting out a lot—he doesn’t listen, he gets into trouble at school, it feels like we’re always on edge with him. My wife and I have been arguing over what to do, and it’s just... exhausting. I’m so stressed all the time, I can’t focus on work, and I don’t even enjoy the things I used to anymore. It’s like everything’s falling apart.

It sounds like you're carrying so much on your shoulders right now. Balancing your son's struggles, the tension with your wife, and the stress it’s putting on your work and overall well-being all at once must feel incredibly draining. It seems like you’re yearning to get back to a place where things feel more stable and enjoyable again. How have you been coping with all this stress?

I honestly don’t think I’ve been coping very well. I just feel drained, like I’m running on empty, and there’s no time or energy left for anything else. Sometimes I try to just push through the day, but it’s hard to even concentrate at work or feel like I’m being a good dad or husband. I don’t even know if I’m doing anything right anymore.

It seems like all of this is really taking a toll on you, leaving you feeling unsure and questioning yourself in so many areas of your life. It’s not easy to keep going when you feel depleted, especially when you're trying to be there for everyone else. I hear a lot of care and concern in what you're saying—clearly, you want to be the best you can for your family. What do you think has helped you get through these tough moments, even when it felt difficult?

Honestly, I’m not sure. I guess I just keep going because I have to. I think about my family and how much I want to help fix things, but it’s hard when I don’t know how. I feel like I don’t have anything left in me most days, and that makes me feel even worse.

It sounds like your love for your family is such a driving force, even when you feel like you’re running on empty. You’re showing a lot of strength just by continuing to push through and keep going for them, even when it feels so hard. It also sounds like struggling to figure out how to fix things leaves you feeling even more drained. What do you think could help you begin to feel like you’re getting a bit of that energy back for yourself?

I honestly don’t know. It feels like everything’s so overwhelming that I don’t even know where to start. I guess maybe if I could figure out how to help my son, things might feel a little less out of control. But I don’t even know if that’s possible.

It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed when so much seems out of control, especially when it comes to wanting to support your son. It sounds like finding a way to help him would give you a sense of direction and maybe bring some relief. Even if it feels unclear right now, just having that hope and desire to help is a powerful start. What are some steps you’ve thought about, or maybe even tried, when it comes to supporting him?

Well, we’ve tried talking to him, grounding him, even rewarding good behavior when we see it, but nothing really seems to work long-term. I’ve thought about therapy for him, but I don’t know if he’d even cooperate, and honestly, I don’t even know where to start with that. It just feels like nothing I do makes a difference, and that’s frustrating.

It’s clear that you’ve been putting a lot of effort into trying different approaches to support him, which shows how much you care and want things to change. It must be so disheartening to feel like, despite all of that effort, things haven’t improved in the way you hoped. Considering therapy for him feels like you’re really trying to explore new ways to help, even though the uncertainty about where to start and how he’d respond makes it feel daunting. What are your thoughts about what therapy might look like for him—or even for yourself—to navigate all of this?

I mean, I’ve thought about it for him, but like I said, I don’t know if he’d even go along with it. As for me, I’m not even sure if it would help. This is my first time even talking to someone like you, and honestly, I’m still pretty skeptical. I just don’t know if anything will actually change.

It’s understandable to feel skeptical, especially when you’ve already been trying so hard to make things better without seeing the results you’re hoping for. You’re here now, though, exploring these possibilities, even if you’re unsure, and that takes courage. It shows that part of you still wants to see things change. What would need to happen for you to feel more hopeful that change is possible?

I guess I’d need to see that something actually works—that there’s some kind of progress, no matter how small. Right now, it’s hard to believe things could really get better when it feels like nothing has in so long. I just want to feel like all of this effort could be worth it.

It sounds like having even a small sign of progress could make a big difference for you, giving you a sense that the effort you’re putting in is meaningful and could lead to change. It’s hard to hold on to hope when you’ve been in the same tough place for a while, but the fact that you’re here, exploring this, shows that you haven’t given up. What would small progress look like for you, either with your son, or even for yourself?

I think even something like fewer fights at home or my son listening more would feel like progress. For myself, maybe just not feeling so heavy and drained all the time. I’m not expecting everything to be perfect, but I’d really just like to feel like we’re moving in the right direction.

Getting to a place where there’s more peace at home and a sense of lightness in yourself sounds like it would really help you feel like things are starting to shift. It’s heartfelt to hear how much you want things to improve—not just for you, but for your whole family. Before we think about next steps, is there anything else that feels important to talk about right now?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
